titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Konstanty Jeleński Papers
titlestmt.author: by Lisa Conathan

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:16

did.unittitle: Konstanty Jeleński papers

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The papers include correspondence, writings and other material that documents Konstanty Jeleński's editorial work, literary criticism and involvement with several cultural organizations, including the Congress for Cultural Freedom, the Royaumont Foundation, and the Institut national de l'audiovisuel. A significant portion of the papers documents Jeleński's translation and criticism of the writings of Witold Gombrowicz. The Papers are not a complete literary archive of Jeleński's life and work and contain only a portion of his correspondence and writings. Series I consists chiefly of Jeleński's general correspondence, writings and writings of others; the remaining series consist of papers related to specific topics and organizations. Correspondents include Witold and Rita Gombrowicz, fellow affilates with the Congress for Cultural Freedom, and publishers. Essays and other writings relate chiefly to mid-twentieth-century Polish literary and political life (especially that of Polish émigrés), to the activities of the Congress for Cultural Freedom, and to Jeleński's translations from Polish to French. Printed material relates to literary, historical and political topics, especially in Poland in the mid- to late- twentieth century. A small amount of material relates to Jeleński's affiliation with the Royaumont Foundation and the Institut national de l'audiovisuel, documenting a portion of the activity of these organizations in the 1970s and 1980s.

langmaterial.language: Material is in French, Polish, and English.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Konstanty Jeleński Papers contains material formerly classed as Uncat Ms Vault 579 and Uncat MSS 122.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 19 contains Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Institut Littéraire on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 1989, and gift of Richard Overstreet and the estate of Leonor Fini, 2001.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Konstanty Jeleński Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Konstanty Jeleński Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

bioghist.head: Konstanty Jeleński, 1922-1987
bioghist.p: Konstanty Aleksander Jeleński (in French: Constantin Jelenski) was born January 2, 1922 in Warsaw, Poland and died May 4, 1987 in Paris, France. At the age of eighteen he left Poland to serve the Polish Army in France. He lived the remainder of his life as an émigré, first in Italy for several years after the Second World War, then settling in Paris in 1951.

In Paris, Jeleński was active in Polish émigré literary circles. He led the Eastern European division of the Congress for Cultural Freedom (after 1967, the International Association for Cultural Freedom) and was a prolific contributor to the Association's monthly publication Preuves and to Kultura , the Polish émigré literary journal. Beginning in 1975, he became increasingly active with the Institut national de l'audiovisuel.

Jeleński's criticism, translations and edited works addresses a wide range of literary, political and artistic topics, especially twentieth-century Polish literature and history. Among his most influential works are many critical essays about Witold Gombrowicz and the edited volume Anthologie de la poesie polonaise (1965).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers include correspondence, writings and other material that documents Konstanty Jeleński's editorial work, literary criticism and involvement with several cultural organizations, including the Congress for Cultural Freedom, the Royaumont Foundation, and the Institut national de l'audiovisuel. A significant portion of the papers documents Jeleński's translation and criticism of the writings of Witold Gombrowicz. The papers are not a complete literary archive of Jeleński's life and work and contain only a portion of his correspondence and writings. Series I consists chiefly of Jeleński's general correspondence, writings and writings of others; the remaining series consist of papers related to specific topics and organizations. Correspondents include Witold and Rita Gombrowicz, fellow affiliates with the Congress for Cultural Freedom, and publishers. Essays and other writings relate chiefly to mid-twentieth-century Polish literary and political life (especially that of Polish émigrés), to the activities of the Congress for Cultural Freedom, and to Jeleński's translations from Polish to French. Printed material relates to literary, historical and political topics, especially in Poland in the mid- to late-twentieth century. A small amount of material relates to Jeleński's affiliation with the Royaumont Foundation and the Institut national de l'audiovisuel, documenting a portion of the activity of these organizations in the 1970s and 1980s.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: I. General Papers of Konstanty Jeleński, 1940-1988. II. Papers Relating to Witold Gombrowicz, 1951-1987. III. Papers Relating to the Congress for Cultural Freedom, 1959-1976. IV. Papers Relating to the Royaumont Foundation, 1970-1973. V. Papers Relating to the Institut national de l'audiovisuel, 1979-1984.

did.unittitle: General Papers of Konstanty Jeleński

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I. is organized into five subseries: Correspondence, Writings, Writings of Others, Visual Material, and Printed Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I documents Jeleński's work as a writer, translator and editor and includes correspondence, writings, visual material and printed material. Correspondents include Witold and Rita Gombrowicz, various publishers, and literary colleagues. Writings include drafts of essays on literature and politics, and writings of others on political and literary issues, focusing on Eastern Europe from the late 1950s through the early 1980s. Visual material includes a portrait of Jeleński in pencil by Bernard Perlin. Printed material includes clippings and copies of articles on policitical and literary issues in Europe in the early 1980s.

did.unittitle: Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters are incoming unless otherwise indicated. Outgoing letters are chiefly carbon copies.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is organized into three subseries: Witold and Rita Gombrowicz Correspondence, Writings, and Other Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II consists of material collected by Jeleński in relation to his critical and editorial work on Gombrowicz and translations of Gombrowicz's writings into French. Several of the writings consist of translations into French, most likely all by Jeleński. The bulk of the series consists of drafts or copies of critical essays about Gombrowicz, by Jeleński and by others. The subseries Other Papers includes a few documents and contracts related to the publishing of Gombrowicz's writings and newspaper clippings on Gombrowicz.

did.unittitle: Witold and Rita Gombrowicz correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unless otherwise indicated, material filed under this heading is photocopies. Dates reflect the original correspondence. Correspondence dated after Witold Gombrowicz's death in 1969 is with Rita Gombrowicz.

Papers Relating to the Congress for Cultural Freedom

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series III is organized into three subseries: Correspondence, Reports and Memoranda, and Printed Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III documents Jelenski's involvement with the Congress for Cultural Freedom. Much of the material dates from the time surrounding a scandal in which ties between the Congress and the Central Intelligence Agency were publicized in 1967. The Congress subsequently changed its name to the International Association for Cultural Freedom. Correspondence is with other affiliates of the Congress and discusses various activities, focusing on Eastern European politics during the 1960s and 1970s. Reports and memoranda document the activities of the Congress in the areas of political activism, the arts, and research into pacifism and violence as methods of social change. Printed material consists of newspaper clippings about the Congress and about topics related to activities of the Congress.

Papers Relating to the Royaumont Foundation

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series IV is organized into three subseries: Correspondence, Notes, Reports and Memoranda, and Printed Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV documents the activities of the Royaumont Foundation in the late 1960s and early 1970s, focusing on the relationships among science, art, and culture. Founded in 1964, the Royaumont Foundation is a private cultural foundation that promotes research in the humanities.

did.unittitle: Correspondence

Papers Relating to the Institut national de l'audiovisuel

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V documents the activities of the Institut national de l'audiovisuel in the late 1970s and early 1980s, focusing on art and film. Founded in 1974, the Institut national de l'audiovisuel is an archival repository for French film and television recordings.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Box 19 contains Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.
